Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Factors Influencing Risk Perception and Movement Decisions in Coastal Louisiana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Short-term environmental disturbances and long-term environmental change have displaced millions worldwide. The US Gulf Coast region is especially vulnerable to the impacts of hurricanes, sea level rise, land subsidence, and flooding. Some parishes in Louisiana have lost over 90% of their land, largely due to environmental changes. What socioeconomic and cultural factors influence perceptions of environment risk and migration? This project investigates factors not traditionally associated with the environment, including ties to place, strong social relationships, and counter perceptions of environmental risk, that might keep people in place, despite environmental risk. Migration theory suggests that behavior is largely linked to economic factors, such as income opportunities or life ambitions. This research, which trains a graduate student in methods of rigorous, scientific data collection and analysis, will investigate whether, and to what extent, environmental perceptions impact movement decisions. Improved understanding of movement decisions can inform local and state decision makers, yielding more precise composite descriptions of their constituents and likely behavioral outcomes, enabling better prediction of migration patterns and strategic planning. Environmental perceptions are also of value to the emergency and first-response communities when they confront new environmental dangers. The ability to better communicate environmental risk or danger can ultimately help to save lives.

Charlotte Till, under the supervision of Dr. Shauna BurnSilver of Arizona State University, will explore the relationship between risk perceptions and migration decisions. This research will be conducted in Terrebonne Parish, Louisiana, an ideal setting for studying risk where there are both acute and chronic stressors on movement behavior. Hurricanes pose a severe seasonal threat to this area, but sea level rise and land subsidence represent cumulative risks and a new everyday reality for coastal people. During pilot study work in the area in 2016 the researchers found that relative to younger residents, older residents had less intention to leave despite known risks, and factors such as home, family, or community were important features of the environment. Based on survey and interview methodologies this research will first identify how the environment is perceived, and then investigate the influence of these perceptions on movement decisions. Survey responses will form the baseline data representing local perceptions, and then a subset of respondents will be invited to interviews allowing the investigator to explore movement logic(s) and the significance of identified influence factors for their decision making. Text analysis tools will be used to analyze interview data. Examples of the insights possible through the findings of this work include: how movement decisions are made, what factors result in place attachment outweighing risk, and how environmental factors interact with movement decisions. By actively incorporating individuals who do not move, this project is targeting an understudied but critical group for analyzing human movement patterns. By drawing participants directly from the parish this research may spur greater public engagement with science, contributing toward greater public scientific literacy. This research contributes to development of the migration literature on the role of the environment in movement decisions and factors impacting those decisions. This project will also facilitate improved understanding and engagement among communities, emergency managers, and municipal respresentatives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Given environmental challenges currently faced by people globally, the goal of this research project was to: better understand how the “environment” factors into decisions to move away from, or stay in, places where environmental risk is high.  Research took place in Terrebonne Parrish, Louisiana USA; an area experiencing sea level rise, and exposed to flooding and hurricanes at increasing intensities.  Scholarship investigating the role of ‘the environment’ in decision making beyond its manifestations as mere physical or climatic features is lacking. This matters because prior research suggests that individuals and families perceive their environment socially, culturally and economically in ways that can; anchor people to stay in unsafe locations, or push people to leave despite intense connections to “place”.  Knowing why people decide leave, or potentially more importantly stay, and the environmental factors that contribute to these decisions is valuable for emergency managers and decision-makers across multiple levels of governance, and will be of increasing importance for coastal communities not only in Terrebonne Parish, but also around the USA, and globally.

After six months of field work, from April-September 2019, and an additional three-week interview collection trip in Feb 2020, the award period of this project is complete. During this time 123 surveys and 63 interviews were achieved with participants across Terrebonne Parish. Participants came from all walks of life as recruitment targeted as wide a range of respondents as possible (older, younger, men and women and across livelihoods).

Despite strong awareness of environmental changes, a majority [56%] of participants indicated that they had no intention to leave their current place of residence. A majority of those who intended to move indicated they intended to remain within Terrebonne Parish [20/53], with a smaller group indicating relocation within Louisiana [15/53]. Findings indicate that ‘the environment’ was conceptualized in nuanced ways by participants. While participants described physical environmental features frequently, more significant were non-tangible elements such as; a sense of place, feelings of community, and memories of place as an anchoring force and a source of both strength and pride.

Elements of the environment that were perceived negatively such as storms, flooding, lack of [economic] opportunities, and community compositional change were named as the main drivers pushing participants to at least consider moving. Demographic considerations such as age were significant for older and younger respondents. A common sentiment from older interviewees was “I do not want to leave, but I know as I get older I likely won’t be able to do this by myself any more”. ‘This’ referred to activities like sand bagging, having the capacity to recover from another storm, or non-environment related concerns like continued personal motility. Though the mind may be steadfast in its desire to remain, there was an awareness that the body may not be up to the task. Alternatively, younger respondents commented that they desired to move to start a family or before their children reached school age. A sizable proportion of older and younger interviewees described very strong connections to place as, “If it turns out I die in this house, then so be it”, “It may get to the point where I can’t protect my property, but there will always be someone to help me do it, that is what life is like down here...this is my home, and I will not leave it”. This participant is not only talking about their home in the sense of their property, but their home in the sense of the broader area, community, and interconnected and overlapping networks of belonging to which they ascribe meaning. These statements emphasize that ‘environment’ extends beyond a physical place and these connections persist despite elevated risk.

A significant component of this research was community outreach. Community members were particularly interested in the environmental focus and having their voices heard, while emergency managers were interested in the findings for people who do not plan to move. During the research period Till presented preliminary results to community groups and interested individuals.  A results dissemination trip is planned for 2021 when Till will return to Terrebonne to share findings directly with study participants, communities, and stakeholders. This will take the form of: Public talks and presentations, discussions with stakeholders and community organizations, and the publication and dissemination of executive summaries.  Anthropological research, its methodology and processes were new concepts to a large proportion of individuals Till interacted with. Thus, sharing results of this project with the community, especially stakeholders in; emergency management, Parish council members, and area planners, who must make decisions that will impact the experience of risk by communities is hugely significant.

This project generated robust qualitative and quantitative results that will potentially lead to improved decision making based upon a more vigorous understanding of environmental factors perceived to be significant to people living with risk in Terrebonne Parish, LA, USA.
